subject: Math
title: Solving Quadratic Equations Graphically
description: Use graphs to find solutions to quadratic equations

content.text: We can solve quadratic equations by finding where the parabola crosses the x-axis. These points are called x-intercepts, roots, or zeros.

content.heading: X-Intercepts and Solutions
content.text:
The solutions to ax² + bx + c = 0 are the x-values where the graph crosses the x-axis (where y = 0).

• Two x-intercepts → two solutions
• One x-intercept → one solution (vertex on x-axis)
• No x-intercepts → no real solutions

content.heading: Example 1
content.problem: If f(x) = x² - 5x + 6 crosses the x-axis at x = 2 and x = 3, what are the solutions to x² - 5x + 6 = 0?
solution: The graph crosses at x = 2 and x = 3

content.heading: Example 2
content.problem: How many solutions does x² + 4x + 5 = 0 have if its vertex is at (-2, 1) and opens upward?
solution: Opens upward and vertex y-coordinate is 1
Since vertex is above x-axis and opens up...
The graph never crosses the x-axis

content.heading: Practice Problems
problems: If a parabola crosses x-axis at 1 and 5, sum of solutions?
If a parabola crosses x-axis at -2 and 4, product of solutions?
If vertex is (3,0) and opens up, how many x-intercepts?
If vertex is (2,-4) and opens up, how many x-intercepts?
If vertex is (1,5) and opens down, how many x-intercepts?
If vertex is (-1,3) and opens up, how many x-intercepts?
If roots are x=2 and x=6, what is axis of symmetry?
If roots are x=-3 and x=1, what is axis of symmetry?
If x-intercepts are at 0 and 8, midpoint?
If parabola touches x-axis at x=5 only, how many solutions?
